title: AB 250
content:
The people of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward," "distant site," and "health care provider." In Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code, terms related to telemedicine are defined, including "originating site" and "synchronous interaction." These terms refer to the location of the patient during telehealth services and real-time interactions between patients and healthcare providers. Telehealth involves delivering healthcare services through technology for diagnosis, treatment, education, and patient self-management. It includes synchronous interactions between patients and distant healthcare providers. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, the provider must inform the patient, obtain consent, and document it. Patients can still receive in-person care if they agree to telehealth services. Non-compliance is considered unprofessional conduct. The failure to comply with telehealth regulations is considered unprofessional conduct. Telehealth does not change the scope of practice for healthcare providers or allow services in unauthorized settings. Patient confidentiality laws apply to telehealth interactions. The regulations do not apply to patients in correctional facilities. The regulations do not apply to patients in correctional facilities. The governing body of the hospital may grant privileges for telehealth services based on medical staff recommendations. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges for telehealth services and verify credentials. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure exams must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks. The applicant must complete a minimum of 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks. This includes not more than 40 hours in any seven consecutive days and at least 1,700 hours after obtaining a qualifying master's or doctoral degree. Additionally, no more than 1,300 hours can be completed before obtaining the degree, with a limit of 750 hours of counseling and direct supervisor contact. Experience cannot be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. No hours of experience may be gained prior to completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Additionally, no more than 1,000 hours of experience in direct supervisor contact are allowed. Not more than 1,000 hours of experience in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities related to marriage and family therapy are allowed. Professional enrichment activities include workshops, seminars, training sessions, or conferences approved by the supervisor, with a limit of 250 hours for attendance. The applicant can participate in personal psychotherapy for up to 100 hours, with three hours of credit for each hour. They can also gain up to 500 hours of experience in group therapy or counseling. Additionally, there is a limit of 500 hours for administering tests, writing reports, and client advocacy after January 1, 2012. Not less than 500 total hours of experience in diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, with specific credit for conjoint therapy. Not more than 375 hours of experience providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or counseling services via telehealth. Not more than 375 hours of experience providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or other counseling services via telehealth, with a focus on working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. This requirement applies to hours gained on and after January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised by a qualified supervisor to ensure counseling is in line with their training. Supervised experience can only be gained as an employee or volunteer, and all laws and regulations must be followed. The requirements for gaining hours of experience and supervision apply to both employees and volunteers, not interns or trainees working as independent contractors. If employed, interns must provide W-2 tax forms for each year of experience. If volunteering, a letter from the employer verifying the intern's volunteer status is required. Supervision must include one hour of direct contact per week for credited experience, except for certain circumstances. A trainee must have one hour of direct supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with a maximum of six hours of supervision per week. Additional supervision is required for individuals with more than 10 hours of client contact per week after obtaining a qualifying degree. Direct supervisor contact is defined as one hour per week of face-to-face contact individually or two hours per week in a group of up to eight supervisees. The contact must occur within the same week as the hours claimed and in segments lasting at least one continuous hour. (5) Direct supervisor contact in a group should involve no more than eight supervisees and last for at least one continuous hour.
(6) Interns in certain settings can use real-time videoconferencing for weekly supervisor contact, ensuring client confidentiality.
(7) The supervisor must monitor all experience gained by a trainee as per regulations. A trainee's experience must be monitored by the supervisor as per regulations. The six hours of weekly supervision can be credited starting from January 1, 2009. Trainees can receive credit for supervised experience in settings that lawfully provide mental health counseling and ensure work meets requirements and scope of practice. An intern can gain experience in settings that provide mental health counseling and psychotherapy, as long as it is not a private practice owned by specific licensed professionals. An intern can gain supervised experience in settings that provide mental health counseling or psychotherapy, with oversight to ensure it meets requirements. They should not work in a private practice until registered, and employers are encouraged to provide fair remuneration. An intern in private practice must be supervised by a licensee who meets specific requirements, except during supervisor's vacation or sick leave. Fair remuneration is encouraged for interns, whether paid or volunteering. To gain experience for licensure, interns must register with the board and apply within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. Experience can only be gained within the position the intern volunteers or is employed in, except in private practice settings where all postdegree hours count towards licensure. Trainees, interns, and applicants must not receive payment from patients or clients, only from their employers. Trainees, interns, and applicants must perform services at their employer's place of business under supervision. They may also provide services via telehealth within authorized scope and regulations. Trainees and interns can provide services via telehealth within authorized scope and regulations, without having any proprietary interest in their employers' businesses. They are not allowed to pay for any obligations of their employers. Trainees, interns, or applicants providing services for reimbursement of expenses up to $500 per month in any lawful work setting are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to verify expenses were actually incurred. Each educational institution and supervisor should consider encouraging students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
